title: Hydroponic Farming Without Electricity: Best Passive Systems

tasks.task: Set up a Kratky hydroponic system
subtasks: Gather materials needed for Kratky system (container, net cups, growing medium, nutrient solution, pH testing kit, seedlings)
Prepare nutrient solution by mixing water and hydroponic nutrients
Adjust pH of nutrient solution to appropriate level for plants (5.5-6.5)
Plant seedlings in net cups filled with growing medium
Submerge net cups in nutrient solution with an air gap at the bottom
Place system in a sunny location (at least 6 hours of sunlight daily)
Monitor nutrient solution level and top up as needed
Change nutrient solution every 2-3 weeks

tasks.task: Prepare a floating raft hydroponic system
subtasks: Identify plants suitable for raft system (e.g., leafy greens, herbs)
Acquire a container for the raft system
Arrange clay pebbles in the container
Fit the raft (a bed of clay pebbles) into the container
Circulate nutrient solution periodically (flooding and draining)
Ensure oxygen reaches plant roots through specialist aeration stones

tasks.task: Maintain a passive hydroponic garden
subtasks: Check plants for adequate sunlight (6 hours per day)
Use high-quality nutrient solutions tailored to plants
Monitor and adjust pH daily to optimal range
Ensure proper air circulation to prevent fungal issues
Look out for signs of nutrient deficiencies and adjust accordingly
Address common mistakes like inadequate lighting or pH imbalances

tasks.task: Experiment with passive hydroponic crops
subtasks: Choose suitable leafy greens (lettuce, spinach, arugula, kale)
Opt for quick-growing herbs like basil, mint, parsley, cilantro
Consider medium difficulty plants such as tomatoes or strawberries (after adapting the system)

tasks.task: Create a hydroponic setup for a small-scale rooftop garden
subtasks: Choose a suitable container for Kratky method (e.g., wide-mouthed glass jar)
Position the container in a rooftop location with adequate sunlight
Prepare a recycling-friendly or low-cost reservoir for nutrient solution
Source affordable materials for net cups and growing medium
Implement a pH testing kit for ongoing care

tasks.task: Transition to a more complex passive hydroponic system
subtasks: Upgrade from Kratky to a wick-based system for larger plants
Acquire materials for wick system (e.g., wicks, more substantial containers)
Experiment with floating rafts for a larger variety of plants
Consider using a clay pebble bed for	root stability and aeration

tasks.task: Troubleshoot common passive hydroponics issues
subtasks: Address leggy, pale plants by increasing light
React to yellowing leaves or stunted growth by adjusting nutrients
Handle pH imbalance through regular testing and adjustments
Manage poor air circulation by enhancing ventilation

tasks.task: Understand the cost-effectiveness of passive hydroponics
subtasks: Compare setup and ongoing costs between passive and active systems
Identify low-cost materials for building passive systems
Note the elimination of electricity costs with passive systems

tasks.task: Share success stories of passive hydroponics
subtasks: Highlight urban rooftop gardens using Kratky method
Showcase off-grid homes utilizing wick systems for vegetable and herb production
Reflect thegenerality of passive hydroponics' adaptability to various environments
